calculator.risk_note_about_household_members: When estimating your risk of infection from a household member or partner/spouse we assume these interactions are indoors, unmasked, and undistanced.

explanationcard.details_person_risk_explanation: First, we calculate that each other person in this area has a {{ person_risk }}-in-a-million chance of currently having COVID.
explanationcard.details_person_risk_explanation_housemat: First, we calculate that each other person in this area has a {{ person_risk }}-in-a-million chance of currently having COVID, not including their risk from living with you.
explanationcard.details_activity_risk_explanation: Next, we calculate the risk of the activity. A person at this activity with COVID would have a {{ activity_risk }} chance of transmitting it to you.
explanationcard.activity_risk_capped_note: (NOTE: We have <2>capped this number at the maximum Activity Risk</2>.)
explanationcard.details_total_risk_explanation: Finally, we multiply Person Risk, Activity Risk, and the number of people to get the total result of roughly {{ points }}-in-a-million ({{ percentage }}) chance of getting COVID from this activity with these people {{ frequency }}.
explanationcard.frequency_explanation_repeated: Since you are seeing these people many times per week, the result you see is microCOVIDs per week.
explanationcard.frequency_explanation_oneoff: Since this is a one-time interaction, the result is shown as microCOVIDs each time you have this interaction. If you do this activity many times in a week, each time you do it, it will count against your weekly budget. If you do this activity many times with the same people each week, enter them as "{{ repeated_type_suggestion }}" to see what the maximum transmission rate is per week.
explanationcard.details_range_explanation: We believe with roughly 90% confidence that the actual risk falls between these two values. See our <2>uncertainty estimation</2>.
explanationcard.risk_budget_header: How much of this can I do given my risk budget?
explanationcard.risk_budget_explanation: You selected an annual budget of a {{ budget_percent }} chance of getting COVID per year ({{ budget_points }} microCOVIDs). That equates to a weekly budget of {{ budget_weekly }} microCOVIDs per week.
explanationcard.risk_budget_usage_explanation: This interaction uses {{ usage }}. This amount of your budget will be used {{ frequency }}.

riskreduction.housemates_header: Here are some ways you can work with close contacts to reduce their risk
riskreduction.housemates_tips:
• Talk to them about how their choices affect your risk, as well as theirs
  • Ask them to MODify their activities (Masked, Outdoors, Distanced)
  • Essential workers can wear a top quality mask (e.g., N95 or KN95) to work <1/>
  • Ask them to limit undistanced socializing to as few people as possible
  • Encourage close contacts to isolate and get tested at the first sign of COVID symptoms
  • If they have high COVID risk and you must be inside with them:
    • Wear masks inside
    • Maximize ventilation using open windows, fans blowing in outside air, and HEPA filters
    • Isolate within the house by staying in different rooms.
riskreduction.onetime_header: Here are some ways of reducing the risk of this activity
riskreduction.onetime_warning: These may or may not apply to your activity.
riskreduction.onetime_tips:
• MODify your activities (make them Masked, Outdoors, Distanced)
  • Wear the best mask you can get!
    <1/>
  • Visit public places during less crowded hours
  • Reduce shopping trips by doing one trip for multiple people, using delivery services, or shopping online
  • If this activity is with friends, encourage them to not come if they or any of their close contacts are feeling unwell

firsttime.microcovid_explanation:
The calculator introduces a new concept, the microCOVID. One microCOVID is a one-in-a-million chance of getting COVID.

An activity that’s 20,000 microCOVIDs is very unsafe, as you have a 2% risk of getting COVID every time you do it. An activity that’s 20 microCOVIDs is relatively safe, as you could do it every week for a year and still have only about a 0.1% chance of getting COVID.
firsttime.budget_header: How can I manage my risk using a risk budget?
firsttime.budget_explanation: We decided an annual risk budget of a 1% chance of catching COVID per year was reasonable for most healthy people who are not in contact with vulnerable groups. To learn how we arrived at that number, <1>click here</1>. If you want to follow this 1%-risk-per-year budget, you’ll want your weekly budget of activities to sum to less than about 200 microCOVIDs each week. We’ve created a handy <3>spreadsheet</3> that lets you keep track of your activities over time.

calculator.risk_tolerance_1_percent_explanation: Budget: 1% chance of COVID per year (200 microCOVIDs per week) (suggested for healthy people NOT in close contact with more vulnerable people)
calculator.risk_tolerance_point1_percent_explanatio: Budget: 0.1% chance of COVID per year (20 microCOVIDs per week) (suggested if you or your close contacts are more vulnerable to COVID)

intro.whats_this:
We’ve constructed a calculator that lets you estimate the risk of getting COVID from an activity or relationship in your daily life, using the <1>best research available. We hope this tool will help hone your intuition, lower your stress levels, and figure out good harm-reduction strategies.

The first step in protecting your family and community is to avoid getting COVID yourself.

warning.body: In this tool we state our best estimate based on available evidence, even when that evidence is not conclusive. We have read a lot of experts' research, but we are not ourselves experts in this topic. This work has not been scientifically peer-reviewed. There is still a lot of uncertainty about COVID. Do not rely on this tool for medical advice. Please continue to follow government guidance.

about.basic_description: This is a project to quantitatively estimate the COVID risk to you from your ordinary daily activities. We trawled the scientific literature for data about the likelihood of getting COVID from different situations, and combined the data into a model that people can use. We estimate COVID risk in units of microCOVIDs, where 1 microCOVID = a one-in-a-million chance of getting COVID.
about.data_inputs_lead: This website contains three outputs of our investigation
about.data_inputs_calculator: a <1>calculator</1> that you can use to calculate your COVID risk
about.data_inputs_whitepaper: a <1>white paper</1> that explains our estimation method
about.data_inputs_spreadsheet: and a <1>spreadsheet</1> to compute your COVID risk in more detail and to track your risk over time.
about.data_inputs_recommendation: You should start with either the <2>calculator</2> or the <5>white paper</5>.
about.disclaimer: <0>Disclaimer</0>In this tool we state our best estimate based on available evidence, even when that evidence is not conclusive. We have read a lot of experts' research, but we are not ourselves experts in this topic. This work has not been scientifically peer-reviewed. There is still a lot of uncertainty about COVID. Do not rely on this tool for medical advice. Please continue to follow government guidance.
